prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gribble-Grabbit

Bewarn the day the Reglets grib,
And strange-scribed furniture grows bib.
When glebbish shapes in corners jounce,
Take heed where horrid notions pounce.

He took his splarch and blimble-lens,
And checked his half-sprogged evidence.
Then, zarking fast, he did intone,
A fooplèd, sputtering new-groan.

And as he vrought with squim and squall,
A Grabbit burfled down the hall.
With flobber-tonsils all aflap,
It issued one vast glimmer-zap!

He plocked the splarch. It gave a gleam,
And rendered things not what they seem.
The Grabbit flurped, then zinched to naught,
A lesson caught, a lesson taught.

Then back he came through glim-gloomed light,
His foe dispatched by clevern might.
Bewarn the way new meanings slip,
When furniture and reglets flip!
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title “The Gribble-Grabbit” present before stanza 1, non-empty and separate.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Poem has 6 stanzas; all stanzas have 4 lines, stanza count is between 5-8 inclusive.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Checking line length alternation by content-word count difference: In at least 4 of 6 stanzas lines alternate longer/shorter with ≥2 content word difference? Alternation is unclear; line lengths and content word counts show less definite alternating long-short pattern. Probably no clear ≥60% stanzas matching this meter alternation.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Checking rhyme of lines 2 and 4 in each stanza: Most stanzas rhyme or slant rhyme (grib/bib; jounce/pounce; lenses/inton(e); squall/hall; gleam/seem; light/flip). No obvious AABB dominance, stanzas mostly ABCB rhyme. So ≥60% stanzas have (2,4) rhyme with varied rhyme scheme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening stanza conceptually (bewarn warning) but does not repeat ≥2 content words/phrases or have clear refrain identical to opening stanza. No explicit ring composition with repeated full lines or strong repeated phrase.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: stanza 1 begins “Bewarn the day...” which is an admonition akin to “Beware...”to protagonist. So yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation/armament: stanza 2 describes protagonist taking his “splarch and blimble-lens”, checking evidence, and intoning spells—this counts as preparation before confrontation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation clear: stanza 3 shows appearance of monster “Grabbit”, stanza 4 describes hostile action (“issued one vast glimmer-zap”), so clear meeting moment.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive act: stanza 5 depicts protagonist acting on monster with splarch, resulting in monster’s end (“zinched to naught”), so decisive action resolving central tension is present.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: stanza 6 depicts return “Then back he came”, foe dispatched, and warning to beware twisting meanings; no explicit jubilant celebration or joy, but a kind of sober conclusion. Lacks jubilant or homecoming acknowledgment tone, more like reflective warning. So probably no.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Counting distinct coinages: gribble, grabbit, bewarn, reglets, blimble-lens, sprogged, fooplèd, sputtering new-groan, vrought, squim, squall, burfled, flobber-tonsils, glimmer-zap, plocked, flurped, zinched, glim-gloomed, clevern - well over 8 distinct coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or invented compound word: yes all 6 stanzas have ≥1 coinage.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature named and central: “Grabbit” is named (non-canonical, not Jabberwock) and is the adversary encountered and defeated, so yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia presence: no obvious classic onomatopoeia bursts or exclamations like “snicker-snack”, “Pop!”, “Hiss!”, or similar emphatic sound effects. Some coined words are sound evocative (e.g., “glimmer-zap”) but not clearly onomatopoeic bursts. Only one possible “glimmer-zap” sound effect. Not ≥2 clear onomatopoeic bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Stanzas show some repeated consonant sounds (e.g., “flobber-tonsils all aflap”, “fooplèd, sputtering new-groan”), but do at least 2 stanzas have clear non-incidental alliteration/consonance beyond incidental? There is decent consonance in stanzas 3 and 4 and stanza 2. So yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: admonition (stanza 1) → preparation (stanza 2) → encounter (3-4) → decisive act (5) → return (6). This matches canonical narrative arc order.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim canonical lines: no exact line duplicates from reference poem.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical word usage: Canonical lexicon largely avoided except "bewarn" a variant of “beware” but that is variant coinage; “then” and “his” normal English not canonical lexicon. No explicit canonical lexicon from the list (brillig, toves, borogoves...). So canonical tokens ≤8 is met favoring new coinages.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable pattern: longer lines about 8–9 syllables, shorter about 5–7 syllables, examining stanza 1: lines count (approx.) line 1 = 6 syll, line 2=6, line 3=7, line 4=6; no clear long/short alternating pattern at canonical levels. Mostly lines around 6-7 syllables, doesn’t strongly replicate Jabberwocky meter of ~8/6. So no.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: (2,4) rhymes mostly unique per stanza, different rhyme endings for all 6 stanzas, no repeated rhyme word >2 times. Yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition: No single content word excessively repeated beyond limits. Coinages mostly unique. So no overuse of single words.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: over 8 coinages with multiple distinct roots, suffix variation visible (e.g., -let, -lens, -zap, -plocked), so ≥4 distinct roots with no single suffix dominating. Yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: The poem addresses an invented creature “Grabbit” and a fanciful confrontation, in the style of Jabberwocky’s nonsense quest; fits topic of matching style and structure to “Jabberwocky”. No topic shift or substitution. Yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: Although poem is playful nonsense, the implied subtext about “bewarning” unusual changes and perception alterations hints at motif about caution versus reality changes and knowledge. Coherent undertone detectable.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued Screw

Beware the Blued Screw, my son!
The gears that catch, the springs that spring!
Beware the Spinning Cog, and shun
The whirring, whizzing Tockamering!

He took his spanner, wrenchy-bright:
Long time the movement-maze he sought—
So rested he by the Fizzy-Fright,
And zizzled there in puzzled thought.

And as in tick-tock thought he stood,
The Blued Screw, with gnashy gear,
Came whirring through the ticklish wood,
And growled and cranked as it drew near!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The spanner went snick-snick!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

And hast thou slain the Blued Screw?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
Oh, flippy-flop day! Hooroo! Hooray!
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Blued Screw, my son!
The gears that catch, the springs that spring!
Beware the Spinning Cog, and shun
The whirring, whizzing Tockamering!
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>No distinct non-empty title line before first stanza; first line is "Beware..." part of stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>7 stanzas total; each stanza has 4 lines; stanza count is within 5-8 range; so yes.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Analyze line lengths for longer/shorter alternation with ≥2 content words difference. Majority of stanzas show alternating long/short pattern (e.g., 1 longer, 1 shorter line alternation) in at least 60% of stanzas; yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Check rhyme (lines 2 and 4) in ≥60% stanzas. Most stanzas rhyme 2 and 4 with slant rhyme allowed. No dominance of AABB pattern evident. Yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats nearly all lines of first stanza including key phrases "Beware the Blued Screw, my son!" and others; this is a clear ring composition with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases; yes.</C5_think>
<C6_think>First stanza functions as a direct admonition "Beware the Blued Screw, my son!"; yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Third stanza shows protagonist taking a spanner, seeking the "movement-maze," resting by the Fizzy-Fright, and contemplating ("zizzled there in puzzled thought"); clearly preparation before encounter; yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Fourth stanza: "The Blued Screw... Came whirring ... growled and cranked as it drew near!" - a clear encounter/confrontation; yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Fifth stanza: "One, two! One, two! And through and through / The spanner went snick-snick! / He left it dead..." Decisive act slaying the adversary; yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Sixth stanza: Return and celebration with embrace and exclamations ("Oh, flippy-flop day! Hooroo! Hooray! / He chortled in his joy."); yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: "Blued Screw," "Spinning Cog," "Tockamering," "wrenchy-bright," "movement-maze," "Fizzy-Fright," "zizzled," "tick-tock," "whirring," "snick-snick," "flippy-flop," "hooroo." Many are coinages. Counting distinct coined forms (excl. standard English) ≥8; yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Every stanza contains at least one coinage: first stanza "Blued Screw," "Spinning Cog," "Tockamering"; second "spanner," "wrenchy-bright," "Fizzy-Fright," "zizzled"; third includes "tick-tock"; fourth "Blued Screw," "whirring," "growled," "cranked"; fifth "snick-snick"; sixth "flippy-flop," "hooroo"; last repeats coinages from first. So yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>"Blued Screw" is a named non-canonical entity, central to action; yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: "snick-snick!" stands out; "whirring," "growled," "cranked," "zizzled" also have onomatopoeic qualities but a bit borderline. Only one clear onomatopoeic burst "snick-snick!" and possibly "whirring," "growled" are more descriptive verbs. Two strong onomatopoeic bursts? No, borderline so no.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Look for clear alliteration/consonance in ≥2 stanzas beyond incidental repeats.
Examples: "spinning Cog," "springs that spring" alliterative s-s, "snick-snick," "spanner went snick-snick," "gears that catch," "growled and cranked," "wrenchy-bright," "flippy-flop day." At least two stanzas show clear alliteration; yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: warning (1st stanza), preparation (2nd & 3rd), encounter (4th), decisive action (5th), return (6th), ring (7th) — proper canonical arc preserved; yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines verbatim from canonical poem. Some similar phrasing but no exact matches (e.g., "One, two! One, two! And through and through" is very similar but not exact; "He went galumphing back" - 'galumphing' is canonical and same as original but line order and context differ; overall no verbatim line; yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used: galumphing, beamish, chortled, one, two, through and through (phrases counted as tokens? no), gone with original canonical lexicon, but only a handful and well below limit 8; yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable pattern check:
Longer lines generally 8-9 syllables (e.g. "Beware the Blued Screw, my son!" 7 syll, but close; "The gears that catch, the springs that spring!" 8 syll; shorter lines mostly 5-7 syll.
Overall pattern roughly aligns with Jabberwocky’s ~8/6 syll.
At least all quatrain stanzas conform to having longer and shorter lines in the expected syllable range; yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: rhymes in stanza 1: son/spring/shun/Tockamering (slant); 2: bright/sought/fright/thought; 3: stood/gear/wood/near; 4: through/snicks/nick/snack? One rhyme repeated (sing along AABB style? No dominant AABB).
Rhymes are varied without repeating exact rhyming words more than twice (excluding ring stanza). Yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Content word repetition: Words like "Blued Screw" and "Beware" repeated, but single content words do not exceed the 5 times or >8% content word limit except for ring stanza repeats.
Also “He” and “the” are function words. No overuse detected; yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: multiple distinct roots present: “Blued Screw,” “Spinning Cog,” “Tockamering,” “wrenchy-bright,” “movement-maze,” “Fizzy-Fright,” “zizzled,” “tick-tock,” “snick-snick,” “flippy-flop,” “hooroo.” No single suffix dominates >50%. Yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topical adherence: Poem clearly addresses a "Blued Screw" analogous to Jabberwock, an adversarial entity; theme matches original poem’s battle with a menace. Fits the topic of a Lewis Carroll style jabberwocky poem; yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: Implied struggle against mechanical menace; theme of coming-of-age/rite of passage in facing a mysterious adversary; repeated warning; motif of clockwork/ticking contrasting with nature; consistent undertones; subtext coherent. Yes.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Murmuration-Swirl**

'Twas brilliant in the fallow field,
The sun-disk made the stubbles gleam,
All twizzly were the furrowed seams,
And zorples whiffled in the stream.

Beware the Murmuration-Swirl,
The swirling-beaks, the twisty-wings,
Beware the whoop-bird on the whorl,
And mubble-murmurs that it brings.

He took his varn-stick snap in hand,
Long time the maxsome foe he sought,
Then stood a-sprawl by the far stand,
And zizzled through his brackled thought.

And as in flaffish thought he stood,
The Murmuration-Swirl arose,
With wheeze of wiff in swillful mood,
And gloffed between the barley rows!

Ziff-zaff! Ziff-zuff! He snapped his stick,
He klorped the snatch-jaw, burled it square,
The Murmuration, glesh and quick,
Went klumpling back to snorpled air.

And hast thou caught the mubble-murmur?
Come to my arms, my blenjie boy!
Oh flazzle-day! Crizz-hizz! Crizz-whirr!
He flummed in burbles of pure joy.

'Twas brilliant in the fallow field,
The sun-disk made the stubbles gleam,
All twizzly were the furrowed seams,
And zorples whiffled in the stream.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "**The Murmuration-Swirl**" is present and non-empty before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Counting stanzas: 8 total, all quatrains (4 lines each), within 5-8 range.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines in each stanza show alternation in length with visible longer and shorter lines alternating in ≥5 stanzas (≥60%), with ≥2 content-word difference.</C3_think>
<C4_think>End rhyme in lines (2,4) present in most stanzas (≥60%), and rhyme pairs vary without a strong AABB pattern (mostly ABCB-like), satisfying this.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza is a full repeat of the first stanza text (4 repeated lines), providing a clear ring composition with more than 2 repeated content words/phrases.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Second stanza contains a clear admonition: "Beware the Murmuration-Swirl," matching the warning style of the canonical poem.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Third stanza shows preparation: protagonist "took his varn-stick snap in hand," "long time the maxsome foe he sought," and "stood a-sprawl by the far stand," indicating preparation and resolve.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Fourth stanza clearly describes the encounter: "The Murmuration-Swirl arose," with actions like "wheeze of wiff," indicating the meeting between protagonist and adversary.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Fifth stanza shows a decisive action: "He snapped his stick," "He klorped the snatch-jaw," and the foe goes "klumpling back," indicating the foe defeated.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Sixth stanza shows return and celebration: "And hast thou caught," "Come to my arms, my blenjie boy," and joyful expressions "Oh flazzle-day! Crizz-hizz! Crizz-whirr!" "He flummed in burbles of pure joy."</C10_think>
<C11_think>Counting distinct coinages: "brilliant" is normal word, but coinages like "twizzly," "zorples," "whiffled," "Murmuration-Swirl," "varn-stick snap," "maxsome," "zizzled," "flaffish," "wheeze of wiff," "gloffed," "Ziff-zaff," "Ziff-zuff," "klorped," "snatch-jaw," "burled," "klumpling," "snorpled," "blenjie," "flazzle-day," "crizz-hizz," "crizz-whirr," "flummed" — the poem easily has more than 8 distinct coinages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coined word (e.g., "twizzly," "zorples," "whiffled," "Murmuration-Swirl," "maxsome," "flaffish," "wheeze," "ziff-zaff," "klorped," "blenjie," "flazzle-day"), so all 8 stanzas have coinage.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature is "Murmuration-Swirl," which is non-canonical, central to action and named repeatedly.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia examples "Ziff-zaff! Ziff-zuff!" and "Crizz-hizz! Crizz-whirr!" present, satisfying requirement for ≥2 onomatopoeic bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration and consonance appear in multiple stanzas, such as "snatch-jaw, burled it square," "Murmuration-Swirl," "wheeze of wiff," "klorped the snatch-jaw," "flazzle-day," "crizz-hizz," and within lines.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order matches canonical poem: warning in stanza 2, preparation in stanza 3, encounter in stanza 4, decisive action in stanza 5, return/celebration in stanza 6, ring echo final stanza.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines verbatim from canonical poem are present; wording and coinages are new, no exact canonical line copied.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used are minimal: "Beware," "And," "he," "in," "long," "time," "the," "he," "stood" appear but canonical invented words ("vorpal," "Jubjub," etc.) are avoided or replaced; presumably canonical token count ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Longer lines mostly near 8–9 syllables, shorter lines about 5–7 syllables; syllabic rhythm and pattern approximate Jabberwocky’s (~8/6) consistently in all stanzas.</C19_think>
<C20_think>End rhymes in lines 2 and 4 vary across stanzas, with different rhyme words used without excessive repetition of same rhyme word >2 times, so rhyme variety satisfied.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word significantly overused outside ring echo; repetitions like "Murmuration-Swirl" are thematic but do not exceed 5 times or 8% threshold.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show a variety of roots and prefixes/suffixes: "twizzly," "zorples," "whiffled," "varn-stick," "maxsome," "zizzled," "flaffish," "wheeze," "gloffed," "klorped," "burled," "klumpling," "snorpled," "blenjie," "flazzle-day," "crizz-hizz," "crizz-whirr," "flummed" come from multiple distinct roots, no dominant suffix >50%.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem clearly matches the "Jabberwocky" themed topic, about a nonsensical creature and hero’s adventure; no deviation from topic.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext or implied motif of caution, bravery, and triumph is coherent across poem similar to canonical poem.</C24_think>
</think>
